member.name: T:Tekla.Common.Geometry.Rectangle3
member.summary: 3D rectangle. Points of the rectangle satisfy equation R(s,t) = C+s0*U0+s1*U1, where C is the center of the rectangle, U0 and U1 are unit-length and perpendicular axes. The parameters s0 and s1 are constrained by |s0| <= e0 and |s1| <= e1, where e0 > 0 and e1 > 0 are called the extents of the rectangle.
member.remarks: Here's a picture where you can see how extents and vertex points are situated:

member.name: M:Tekla.Common.Geometry.Quaternion.Inverse
member.summary: Returns the inverse of this quaternion. The original quaternion Q and the inverse quaternion Q* fulfill the equation QQ* = I (I is identity quaternion).

member.name: M:Tekla.Common.Geometry.Quaternion.Conjugate
member.summary: Returns the conjugate of this quaternion. If quaternion Q = w + x*i + y*j + z*k, the conjugate is w - x*i - y*j - z*k.

member.name: M:Tekla.Common.Geometry.Quaternion.Exp
member.summary:
If quaternion q = A*(x*i+y*j+z*k) where (x,y,z) is unit length, then exp(q) = cos(A)+sin(A)*(x*i+y*j+z*k).
If sin(A) is near zero, this method uses formula exp(q) = cos(A)+A*(x*i+y*j+z*k) since A/sin(A) has limit 1.

member.name: M:Tekla.Common.Geometry.Quaternion.Log
member.summary:
If quaternion q = cos(A)+sin(A)*(x*i+y*j+z*k) where (x,y,z) is unit length, then log(q) = A*(x*i+y*j+z*k).
If sin(A) is near zero, this methods uses log(q) = sin(A)*(x*i+y*j+z*k) since sin(A)/A has limit 1.

member.name: T:Tekla.Common.Geometry.Circle3
member.summary: 3D circle. The plane containing the circle is Dot(N,X-C) = 0, where X is any point in the plane and C is the center point of the circle. Vectors U, V, and N form an orthonormal right-handed set (matrix [U V N] is orthonormal and its' determinant is 1). The circle with radius R within the plane is parameterized by X = C + R*(cos(t)*U + sin(t)*V), where t is an angle in [-pi,pi].

member.name: T:Tekla.Common.Geometry.Segment3
member.summary: 3D segment. The segment is represented as P+t*D, where P is the segment origin, D is a unit-length direction vector and e >0 |t|. The value e is the extent of the segment.
